definition[0]: if something breaks up, or if you break it up, it breaks into a lot of small pieces
example[0]: It seems that the plane just broke up in the air.
example[1]: Use a fork to break up the soil.
definition[1]: to separate something into several smaller parts
example[2]: There are plans to break the company up into several smaller independent companies.
example[3]: You need a few trees and bushes to break up the lawn.
example[4]: Three policemen were needed to break up the fight.
definition[3]: to make people leave a place where they have been meeting or protesting
example[5]: Government soldiers broke up the demonstration.
example[6]: Police moved in to break up the meeting.
definition[4]: if a marriage, group of people, or relationship breaks up, the people in it separate and do not live or work together anymore
example[7]: He lost his job and his marriage broke up.
example[8]: The couple broke up last year.
example[9]: Many bands break up because of personality clashes between the musicians.
example[10]: Has Sam really broken up with Lucy?
definition[5]: if a meeting or party breaks up, people start to leave
example[11]: The party didn’t break up until after midnight.
example[12]: The meeting broke up without any agreement.
definition[6]: when a school breaks up, it closes for a holiday
example[14]: When do you break up for Easter?
definition[7]: to make someone laugh by saying or doing something funny
definition[8]: if a company or group breaks up or is broken up, it is divided into smaller companies
example[16]: The new chairman plans to break up the group into more autonomous subsidiaries.
definition[9]: if someone breaks up an arrangement or agreement, or if it is broken up, it ends
example[17]: Japan’s Fair Trade Commission ordered 13 ink makers to break up a price-fixing cartel.
definition[10]: an occasion when a company or group is broken up into smaller units
example[18]: Break-ups create added tax, interest and management costs.
